name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @fiagirly @nazm14_ @tarmactorque Absolutely all for that, especially broadening perspectives Hope those efforts go from strength to strength! Happy New Year

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @tarmactorque I'm always keen to listen and learn. And if there's ever something that might be useful from my perspective or experiences I'm absolutely happy to share.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @nazm14_ @tarmactorque I'm very pleased to hear they are well received. And sorry, I wasn't sure whether it would be weird to tag you in the original message! Full credit to you all (including @fiagirly as I now think it might OK to tag...)

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @tarmactorque That's a kind offer, thank you. I wouldn't like to overstep though. When it comes to the issue of race, my place is to listen more than speak!

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @tarmactorque Yeah, let's see. On a separate note, I listened to this:  https://t.co/jRDcm1sSTq I wasn't sure whether I should acknowledge it as I didn't want to sound patronising but I sincerely respect it. The emotion underlined how important a conversation it is. I hope #F1 embraces it more.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @tarmactorque Rightly skeptical. I'm interested to see how the FIA reconciles a complete justification of what happened (stewards' decision) with apparently needing to review what happened and make improvements. Mercedes might have some tools to hold the FIA to account as Wolff promised.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @tarmactorque I think how the powers-that-be react to Abu Dhabi is a defining factor in F1's balance between sport and entertainment. And even looking past the last race I think we've all felt that tilt one way over the last couple of years.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @_the44 @f1blag @PG876 @GavinWhitaker @fia The only thing I can see being made 'better' for Lewis is actually giving him faith he can trust the system. That's a huge thing. It's not Lewis's responsibility to 'just accept it and move on' or 'come back stronger'. They have to prove to him the governing body is up to it.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @_the44 @PG876 @GavinWhitaker I understand what you mean in the first reply about "eligible" vs "worthy".  I wasn't rooting for either, so I only use 'worthy' in the context of the year as a whole. LH deserved it on the night. So I hope you understand I don't believe what happened in Abu Dhabi is justifiable.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @f1blag @PG876 @GavinWhitaker @_the44 @fia Yeah, absolutely, because the absolute bare minimum is that this is learned from and a repeat never happens. Would never pretend that just fixes what happened in Abu Dhabi though.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @_the44 @PG876 @GavinWhitaker I agree it's certainly not justification. I do think 'Max is a worthy champion' is a valid opinion to have but whenever I've expressed that, it's meant as a separate observation rather than 'come on, just let it go'. Definitely doesn't make what happened in Abu Dhabi OK/correct.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @PG876 @GavinWhitaker @_the44 I know the exact same piece can please/piss off all sides. Sadly I can‚Äôt stop people believing I have certain biases/views. But I do what I think is right. I‚Äôve been critical of the FIA on many issues including this. Yet I get accused of defending them. Comes with the territory.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @PG876 @GavinWhitaker @_the44 I‚Äôve criticised the FIA, said it was handled wrongly and unfair, said there must be changes and even highlighted a problem with the FIA court. You think I‚Äôm sweeping it under the rug, the FIA thinks I‚Äôm defamatory, extreme Max fans think I‚Äôm a crybaby. So I‚Äôm pretty stumped!

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @PG876 @GavinWhitaker @_the44 You are if you‚Äôre claiming we‚Äôre not holding anyone to account. Which is presumably because we‚Äôre not doing/saying exactly what you want us to. But that‚Äôs not the same thing.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @PG876 @GavinWhitaker @_the44 I don‚Äôt expect people to have read/listened to/watched everything we‚Äôve done. But if you haven‚Äôt, you shouldn‚Äôt make a sweeping claim that we haven‚Äôt held them to account. Pre-Xmas I got accused of defamation. That wouldn‚Äôt have happened if we‚Äôd just brushed it all aside.

name: Scott Mitchell

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @RobBooth96 @wearetherace He made the same decision as Hamilton. Did Hamilton‚Äôs inexperience show?

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @RobBooth96 @wearetherace Because as I wrote in the piece at the start of all this, it‚Äôs wrong to think all the drivers were making their decisions in the exact same circumstances. They weren‚Äôt. Ricciardo was struggling more than Norris. And he didn‚Äôt have a win on the line. So bailing for inters was easy

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @RobBooth96 @wearetherace At the time he was asked the inter wasn‚Äôt necessary. So he was right. And McLaren said the same thing as Norris after Hamilton pitted. They both knew by that point they were all-in.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @RoryMitchell Russell didn‚Äôt have a win on the line, so that‚Äôs not a matter of experience - it‚Äôs very different circumstance to operate under, easier to play it safe

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @rxvaldo I don‚Äôt think the radio is a big deal. Those radio clips didn‚Äôt happen that close together. But the first one he snapped while wrestling the car as it was superfluous info. And the track was still dry enough when they asked what he thought about inters so he shouted a sharp ‚Äúno‚Äù

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @tarmactorque And in a situation like that it ends up being pivotal because Lewis gets the call and while he initially doubted it - hence staying out - he eventually gave ‚Äúblind faith‚Äù (his words) in the team. McLaren need to be more assertive. They‚Äôll get there I‚Äôm sure. But it cost LN a win.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @tarmactorque Norris wasn‚Äôt let down by his own inexperience, though. And that‚Äôs what Brawn said. He said Lewis did something Lando didn‚Äôt because of experience. But by Lewis‚Äôs own admission he wouldn‚Äôt have pitted, until he realised the team was adamant. Merc made the call, McLaren wouldn‚Äôt.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @RobBooth96 @wearetherace What are you basing the claim he ‚Äúthought he knew best‚Äù on? All he could judge were live track conditions. Which he did well. Until the rain that the team didn‚Äôt anticipate arrived. And at no point did Norris get a radio message telling him to pit. So he never overruled his team.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: Had a few people say Brawn is right. He isn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs not a matter of opinion it‚Äôs fact. Lewis didn‚Äôt make the call to stop. He said it was his team. What Lewis did was (eventually) follow a clear order to pit - an order Lando didn‚Äôt get. So it‚Äôs simply wrong to compare directly.

tweet: @AnneleahF1 @goonerhamfosi I think allowing for interpretation and having consistency are both achievable as long as the same logic is being used for the interpretation and the same opportunity to interpret is given. Unfortunately this is where F1's rules get messy.

tweet: No Verstappen penalty for passing Stroll under red flags. There was a speed delta of 150kph and Verstappen was only "a few metres" behind at the point of receiving the red light on his dash - so stewards feel momentum took him past. Full story/explanation:  https://t.co/BGnkjlxx5p

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @AnneleahF1 @goonerhamfosi I might be wrong. I think it's fractionally quicker. Either way I think at most Vestappen has two seconds here between a red light and passing Stroll. It may be that given the closing speeds they determine he slowed appropriately and circumstances made the pass unavoidable.

No idea why maybe it's just quicker getting the message. But the point of drivers being notified is actually a second or two after this.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @swiftsambi @capt_blockchain @PranushaReddy93 For reference that graphic comes on screen before the light panels at the side of the track or the message on the wheel

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @GhostJames14 @swiftsambi @PranushaReddy93 Can you tell the Dutch fans who think I'm hopelessly biased towards Hamilton, please? I don't think they realise I'm actually Team Verstappen.  And a polite correction, I'm not an F1 YouTuber I'm an F1 journalist.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @goonerhamfosi No driver should be penalised for what happened in this incident. The track where Verstappen is goes instantly from green to red. He's probably 2 or 3 metres from Stroll when the red light shows, travelling at a much higher speed. He'd go past even with instant 100% braking.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @GhostJames14 @PranushaReddy93 @swiftsambi He did as soon as was reasonably possible.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @GhostJames14 @PranushaReddy93 @swiftsambi Based on Stroll's onboard there is ~2s between the red light signal and Verstappen going past. So you think that in around 2 seconds Verstappen should notice the red light, slow down from a speed of maybe 80mph more than Stroll and stop an overtake from probably 2 metres back?

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @GhostJames14 @PranushaReddy93 @swiftsambi Why? What data or evidence do you have to state that?

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @PranushaReddy93 @swiftsambi You must factor in the time taken to react and the speed offset. There has to be some leeway for Verstappen to get on the brakes. He has to slow down safely. And he is travelling much faster than Stroll. So even if he jumped 100% on the brakes instantly, he'd still overtake him.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @swiftsambi @PranushaReddy93 Not seeing a board that has relevant information while travelling at reduced speed is not the same as the time it takes to notice a flashing light panel when you're travelling at full speed.   This is why comparing different incidents doesn't work. They simply aren't the same.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @swiftsambi @PranushaReddy93 Right, but "if at this moment if the car displays rapid deceleration" is colossally unrealistic. You're looking out for a red flag there. Verstappen isn't. It will take some time - even a matter of tenths of a second - to react. And the closing speed is enormous.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @swiftsambi @PranushaReddy93 It is equivalency if you're stating that previous incidents are the same or similar to this one.  Watch the footage and tell me honestly how Verstappen is meant to act differently, and how that specific set of circumstances can have a different outcome?

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @PranushaReddy93 @swiftsambi Doesn't change anything that I've said. Lewis was punished in Austria last year because new video footage showed he should have slowed for double waved yellows that were clearly visible. This is a totally different incident. The constant false equivalency is quite frustrating.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @DaanWmn Exactly. Would share that very clip if I was allowed to. Even when you're looking out for the red flag it comes out fractionally before Verstappen is set to pass Stroll. It's wrong to expect him to notice it and slow down sufficiently to not pass him in the time he has.

name: Scott Mitchell

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @KphMotorsport @wearetherace But they weren‚Äôt crash in the manner they did - into each other. That‚Äôs the problem. Hitting the wall is OK, cars are designed for that. Being in a position to be hit by other cars that easily is not. As explained in the article.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @KphMotorsport @wearetherace From the very beginning my point was that the walls/runoff there create problems and that‚Äôs the common link. I‚Äôve never said they were identical.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @KphMotorsport @wearetherace Not all the cars would have collided. And those that did may well have collided less severely. There is no doubt that the run off and positioning of the barriers made today‚Äôs accident much worse and more dangerous.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @KphMotorsport @wearetherace You only need one car to hit the wall to create a massively dangerous scenario. That accident wouldn‚Äôt happen at all the same way if there was extended run-off. They wouldn‚Äôt all be piling into the same confined space - especially the final car - with cars parked by the wall.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @RoryMitchell They do but what other corners in F1 have the same combination of speed/blindness/barrier proximity/limited runoff? So the risk is basically that you could drive that corner completely normally, get to the top, and have a car parked in your way. I think it‚Äôs a unique risk.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @KphMotorsport @wearetherace Can‚Äôt think of many F1 tracks (if any) with a corner that has the same combination of issues as Eau Rouge/Raidillon for barrier proximity and limited runoff at that speed.  But those safety changes are exactly what are outlined in the piece

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @KphMotorsport @wearetherace No but all the cars that went off were instantly hittable because the barrier/run-off is right on the edge of the track

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: Tried to take as considered a view on the Eau Rouge/Raidillon situation as possible. Think the element that needs changing is the run-off and if that could happen then you save the corner itself. If it‚Äôs not possible then I think the risks are wrong.

tweet: @MartinStrumpfer No way are the teams not trying to take advantage of this if exemptions are allowed. name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @justinsands @CharleneClair I'm sure there would be some kind of system enforced. But they aren't going to match the manufacturers for technical capacity. So at some point there is going to be a difference between what the manufacturer sees as an engine problem and the FIA sees. That gap is a problem.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @JJDyson All the checks indicated Max's engine was fine. The crack appeared after four sessions of running in Hungary. Now, I believe that is still a legacy of the Silverstone crash. But could Honda prove that? Otherwise would be open to challenge by rivals. It could get really messy.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: The part I find the least fair on innocent teams/drivers is the engine issue. But I don't know the solution that covers making sure stated engine damage is real, stopping drivers getting an advantage for future races with a 'free' PU change, and keeping development costs down.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @sozmarra I honestly don't know but I assume the teams do the repairs and then take whatever the punishment is for breaching the regs. That's the thing with brand new financial regs, need to see how they work in reality to tweak and improve them where necessary. But it's quite complicated!

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @pawelf1 Yeah, that is where it will get particularly interesting. I think we need real case studies from this year to work it out

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @CharleneClair My concern with that is what if you're five or six races in with an engine, and you get wrecked. Is it right that the driver gets a completely fresh one free of charge, when it was near the end of its life anyway? Not sure how you square it.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @MaxPeck69 Impossible to understand it to be honest, the handling of track limits is a mess. All I can say, having also checked with various drivers and teams, is that it had been made clear that for T4 the FIA was ignoring the white line *unless* a driver went over it to make a pass.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @howster34 Haven't stood up for anyone. Just explained what the rules were. Even said it was silly to have that inconsistency.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @SGJohnMcClane You haven't really read what I've written if you think that's "defending him". I've just explained why one thing was punished and the other wasn't. Even said it doesn't make sense to be inconsistent with the rules. And that happened about 10 years before I covered F1, so...

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: So, the rules are quite 'clear'. Are they consistent? No. That's what's silly. It becomes needlessly controversial. Also murky when drivers/team bosses say the rule changed mid-race + they were warned not to run wide on the exit of Turn 4 at all, but Masi says that didn't happen.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: Worth pointing out that Hamilton was not the only driver to do this, even Verstappen did it once Red Bull appeared to get clarification it was OK. But Hamilton obviously did it prolifically and also benefitted from Verstappen's pass being illegal, hence the focus here.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: Crucially, in this instance lasting advantage means 'overtake someone'. And that's what drivers were told too. So, any driver (like Hamilton) could go off-track on their own multiple times. But going off while completing an overtake (like Verstappen) would not be allowed.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: The T4 rules changed after FP1. In FP2/3 and Q, you couldn't cut behind exit kerb. But in the race it was decided that track limits would "not be monitored" there. Drivers were told they could run off-track at T4 if they did not gain a lasting advantage.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: Seen a lot of comments/anger why officials didn't punish Hamilton for going wide at Turn 4 for half the race but intervened after Verstappen made a pass off-track was correct. It was correct based on the rules for the race itself + what drivers were told:  https://t.co/ONbqpiTDw0

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: RT @wearetherace: Why #F1 race director Masi ruled that Hamilton's repeated trips off the road at #BahrainGP Turn 4 were OK, but Verstappen‚Ä¶

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @ArGaMer0 Comes down to interpretation of "not monitoring" I think. Not policed with regular warnings, but sporting regs still in force including "for the avoidance of doubt, any white lines defining the track edges are considered to be part of the track but the kerbs are not".

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: My position in this is 'yes but the rules had already been undermined'. Track limits management at Turn 4 was not fit for purpose this weekend and it was a shame it was so unclear/inconsistent. There shouldn't be any issue with that overtake being illegal.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @bethonieboost I do understand that argument. Personally I don't agree because racecraft is practiced in karts/early years of cars. F2 should be a finishing school for the best drivers in my opinion. Instead reverse grids are part of a big package to make races as unpredictable as possible.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @BenHockingF1 I'm sure that will be one of the main arguments for it but it doesn't wash with me, partly because the reward for working hard with team and nailing qualifying/result is being put to the back of a probable DRS train with spec machinery.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: I don't believe F1 needs/should have all those variables. The point of my tweet (which I should have been clearer on) is that Formula 2 has them all, which to me is much worse. I can understand the argument F1 should be entertainment. But not F2, F3, or other junior series.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @AgileHarvey I'm not saying I support that happening in F1. Just that it's a great way to inject entertainment. Formula 2 is the subject of my ire (which I wasn't clear about). It shouldn't exist to entertain. These variables are counter-productive to what should be its core purpose.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: Reversing race results to set grids, reversing qualifying to set grids, high-deg tyres and unreliable cars. Lots of variables (mostly artificial) to mix things up, a great way to create entertainment in #F1. I'll never be convinced it's acceptable for a training ground series.

tweet: I‚Äôve seen friends, family, loved ones, colleagues and strangers all sharing powerful accounts that are so frighteningly close to the Sarah Everard case. Those sharing their stories deserve respect, compassion, and action. Not patronising remarks and victim blaming.

tweet: The replies to this are just a glimpse at how deep the anxiety can be for women walking on their own, especially at night. It‚Äôs a good look at how we might scrutinise and adjust our own actions. Because the solution mustn‚Äôt be ‚Äòwomen can‚Äôt walk alone at night‚Äô. That‚Äôs twisted.

name: Scott Mitchell

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @robefc @BoneyAbroad Ah I just meant included what I could in terms of what stories have been openly talked about by the Verstappens. There are always other rumours but it's dangeorus and unfair to present them as fact.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @RedbeardRohan @wearetherace As I've said to others: first, 'abuse' has a specific and legal connotation to it. Second, it was a feature not an opinion piece. I wanted to put that bad stuff out there as it's a relevant part of the story, make people aware of it and let them draw their own conclusions.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @franevaldez @RedbeardRohan @wearetherace I think I agree with all those points!

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @BoneyAbroad Truthfully, as it was a feature not an opinion piece, my priority was to put that bad stuff out there so people were aware of it and could draw their own conclusions on the methods. As a whole, but also the specifcs that are nasty to a lot of people (including myself).

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @BoneyAbroad That's a shame because that was never a consideration at all. I don't have any access to Jos to lose, for starters. I wanted to write about Verstappen's racing upbringing. I didn't want to pretend the bad stuff didn't happen so included what I could. No more or less than that.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: Deal done: Lewis Hamilton stays with Mercedes - so far only announced for 2021. "A significant part of the new agreement builds upon the joint commitment to greater diversity and inclusion in motorsport." Includes setting up a charitable foundation:  https://t.co/XEG87N6Y0E

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: #AnnounceBio

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @HSouthwellFE True. I don't know for sure it wasn't 'because of' but I hope it wasn't! For me those stories were important to include but never sought to glorify/endorse.   'Tough love' is now in quote marks. It's not editorial, it's a quote reference, and that was a mistake from me.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @NavalAirHistory @HSouthwellFE No but I'm just mentioning that in the context that Jos Verstappen - like many others - believes the ends justified the means. Personally I don't believe that so my point here is that I could have called out some specific stories and said there was a better way to handle that.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @AmDessex I bet everybody who raced has stories like that. Or played football! I know I have a few from both. For those who went through it, it seems normal. For those who didn't, it's extreme - and I understand that. I think it crosses a line but others will see it as 'tough love'.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @franevaldez @RedbeardRohan @wearetherace I understand why you're saying that. I'd just stress it's important to consider that 'abuse' carries a very specific and legal connotation which is especially dangerous in the context of Max's childhood. I thought a lot about how to frame it. Maybe I could/should've been clearer.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @HSouthwellFE But they are part of the process that shaped him as a driver so they can't just be ignored. Perhaps I was wrong not to state there were less troubling ways to achieve the result. As it was a feature not opinion I honestly just wanted to let people make their own judgements.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @HSouthwellFE That's not quite true as the reference to unconventional methods comes just before, about practicing overtaking.   I don't endorse the nastiness. I've been though many of those experiences. It's simply a story worth telling, if only to highlight things that shouldn't be repeated.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @RedbeardRohan @wearetherace Some might say it‚Äôs normal too (a lot of it wasn‚Äôt dissimilar to what I experienced at times). But that‚Äôs not a good thing. Personally I think the methods are outdated and there are better ways to achieve the result. The points is it‚Äôs not glorifying it, it‚Äôs telling the story.

name: Scott Mitchell

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: One of many sad consequences of today is some nasty views are now being expressed. Bullies feeling vindicated.The aggressive defences are rooted in ‚Äúfacts‚Äù that are actually uncertainties. Which is why, and I won‚Äôt stop repeating this, it needed an independent investigation.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @AlexBC997 @JennieGow All this ‚Äúbeta male‚Äù (whatever that means in your world) wants is a proper investigation to establish the facts and remove the grey areas.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @AlexBC997 @wouter_max You can care about more than one issue. You can be troubled by more than one problem. And Saudi is a problem. It has been questioned and will continue to be. But you should stop using other other issues to detract from things that matter as well. Like Mazepin.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @AlexBC997 @JennieGow Or maybe because her first account wasn‚Äôt accurate? At the very least it should be clarified. Not just dismissed as you seem to want it to be. He himself admitted it was inappropriate.  Why should people who do bad things avoid scrutiny? What if it really wasn‚Äôt just a joke?

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @AlexBC997 @wouter_max That‚Äôs not what I said. What I said is that focusing on one issue that‚Äôs happening at present doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre ignoring other issues or never going to tackle them. Lots of issues need attention/action. But ‚Äòwhataboutery‚Äô like that is hugely unhelpful.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @AlexBC997 @JennieGow The apology has been withdrawn from the public domain. And the young woman subsequently issued pointed remarks that suggested all was not well. At the very least it merited further enquiry. You should consider the damage that is done by people never scrutinising such behaviour.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: As I‚Äôve written already, if he‚Äôs not found guilty of any serious wrongdoing he won‚Äôt be treated as guilty. And I wouldn‚Äôt expect otherwise. But this was a public incident that stoked a hugely emotional response. ‚ÄúDealt with internally‚Äù doesn‚Äôt offer remotely satisfactory closure.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @bnlflo Could have been looked into officially. Could still be. Hope it is. Otherwise shows F1/FIA isn‚Äôt serious about making sure the moral standards they espouse are upheld. Can‚Äôt just accept an unknown internal resolution. But then we did have a ‚Äòconfidential settlement‚Äô over Ferrari.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @wouter_max We have a bit and we will continue to do so more. But right now there‚Äôs a specific issue that is in the news and it needs addressing. Not dismissed by whataboutery. Just because focus is on one thing doesn‚Äôt mean nothing else matters/it‚Äôs all being ignored.

name: Scott Mitchell

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @bethonieboost That argument could be made and I think it would lose. Because facts are what matter most especially in an incident like this, not interpretations over a single word. Which is why I've called for a proper investigation. To establish key details. And make any action more robust.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @bethonieboost After he admitted to being "inappropriate". Which is vague. It could mean anything. And 'I think he meant this' is not a strong legal position. Especially compared to her statement, which fully shifted responsibility for the worst aspects of it away from him.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @bethonieboost Guessing what he thought was inappropriate would be worth nothing in court. Which is why a proper investigation is necessary, to eliminate the grey areas. Establish what was inappropriate and also clarify the young woman's stance. Because her first statement exonerated him.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @bethonieboost There are/can be penalties for inappropriate behaviour, sure. But it depends what "inappropriate" means. I don't think it's anywhere near enough to try to get out of a multi-million dollar contract.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @bethonieboost To a point, yeah. It means there's an admission of some kind of guilt. But "inappropriate" doesn't mean illegal and that's at the heart of the problem when it comes to assessing the consequences. It's why it's necessary to see F1/FIA scrutinise the whole thing more.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: It's good to see Haas and Williams use their nominated reserves, but those teams have less to fight for. So they just need Fittipaldi/Aitken to fill a gap. Mercedes need more than that plus want to evaluate Russell for the future. It was a no-brainer to push for him.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: I'd have loved the story of redemption had Mercedes promoted its reserve driver Stoffel Vandoorne but it's not obliged to use him. Back-up drivers are there for emergency use. If this happened Thursday/Friday, I'm sure Stoffel's in. But there was time to get a better option.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @luttren They want to get everyone in a single, short queue as quickly as possible. That gives the marshals more time to deal with whatever problem has caused the safety car (e.g. 70 seconds with no cars coming past). Lapped cars then get released when it's considered safe.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @luttren That's part of why Stroll was pushing so much to catch up, yeah. But it doesn't excuse how quickly he went through that area. The S2 times don't mean that Stroll was 7s faster than Kimi through the double-waved yellows, they just support the fact he didn't really back off.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: RT @wearetherace: Unnerving footage of Stroll running at speed past marshals working on track during the Imola #F1 safety car period raises‚Ä¶

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: This needs reviewing, to evaluate if double-waved yellows are sufficient (Raikkonen saw them and slowed so why not Stroll), ask if teams should communicate more (Grosjean was told, others weren't), and avoid a dangerous precedent (presumably Stroll unpunished as nobody noticed).

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: FIA relied on double waved yellows being observed when lapped cars were released with marshals working trackside. Stroll did not "significantly" slow. S2 times supports that - 7s quicker than Raikkonen, 3.5s quicker than Vettel, only 1s slower than Stroll‚Äôs fastest S2 all race.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @alexistwts @patrik_hansson @wearetherace @eddstrawF1 @SportmphMark Yeah but that's because of where the safety car lights went out. So it's all inter-connected.   *If* the lights went out earlier, then ideally Bottas would back them up early. Then blitz it to the final corner.   But they didn't, so the instruction was 'crawl, VB, crawl!'

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @patrik_hansson @alexistwts @wearetherace @eddstrawF1 @SportmphMark Should be everybody. I actually find the '10 car lengths apart' really difficult for a driver to judge by eye! Who knows what the FIA have to measure that with, or what they are looking at. It's all a bit messy...

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @patrik_hansson @alexistwts @wearetherace @eddstrawF1 @SportmphMark I think Bottas would have accelerated before the final corner. My understanding is that was Mercedes' preference - so he'd aim to gap Hamilton before the final corner, stay ahead (it's hard to follow there at speed) and then not be under attack all the way down the main straight.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @Nauckas @EliGP @LukeSmithF1 I couldn't help myself

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @patrik_hansson @alexistwts @wearetherace @eddstrawF1 @SportmphMark Sorry if that was unclear or we got confusing in what we said. What I meant, or should have said, is that when you can't back the field up earlier *then* the best strategy would be to wait until the line. If the lights went off earlier VB would have backed them up before chicane.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @alexistwts @patrik_hansson @wearetherace @eddstrawF1 @SportmphMark Sorry, I should clarify. In the rules the 'safety car ending' message IS meant to trigger the lights going out. But it didn't here. The lights stayed on until the very end of the lap. Bizarre given it seems to contravene FIA's own rules. But that's what forced Bottas to wait.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @alexistwts @patrik_hansson @wearetherace @eddstrawF1 @SportmphMark Which means he waits until the last possible opportunity to floor the throttle - at Mugello that was quite a long way down the straight.

name: Scott Mitchell
tweet: @alexistwts @patrik_hansson @wearetherace @eddstrawF1 @SportmphMark The 'safety car ending' message is just a heads up to the teams, it doesn't impact the restart procedure itself. Bottas can't drop more than 10 car lengths behind the safety car until the safety car turns its lights off. The later the happens, the more it restricts his options.
